thread.section_title: High School Sports, Prep Sports in Los Angeles, San Fernando Valley: Los Angeles Daily News
thread.title: St. Francis football hands Cathedral first loss
thread.title_full: St. Francis football hands Cathedral first loss

author: Vincent Nguyen, Correspondent
title: St. Francis football hands Cathedral first loss
text:
LA CANADA FLINTRIDGE >> St. Francis High School ended two things Friday night.
After losing on a Hail Mary last week and losing in double overtime the week before, the Golden Knights snapped a three-game losing streak.
And St. Francis did so in style, as wide receiver Jasher Foster scored on a 90-yard punt return and then an 18-yard rushing touchdown to defeat previously undefeated Cathedral 31-14 in a Angelus League matchup.
“It’s huge for morale,” said St. Francis head coach Jim Bonds. “It shows a lot of character from our guys to come out to play the way they did tonight.”
Amid investigation for a hazing incident earlier this week involving 10 of its players, Cathedral (7-1, 2-1) could not hold up its undefeated run.
“It would have been great to have been in full strength, but we’ve just got to get better,” said Cathedral head coach Kevin Pearson of his team’s depleted roster. “It’s unfortunate that a bunch of silly mistakes effect so many people.”
Bonds did not focus too much on the incident, and turned his attention more toward his team during the week.
“All their skill players were intact,” said Bonds. “We just went out there in our status quo and worried about ourselves because we had enough to work on.”
St. Francis receiver Jace Harrick scored his team’s first two touchdowns to keep the Golden Knights (5-3, 1-2) in the game. Cathedral’s Jamire Clavin scored on a 92-yard punt return before quarterback Andrew Tovar ran it in the end zone for a 28-yard touchdown.
Tovar started the game off throwing an interception to St. Francis’ Sean Davitt. The Golden Knights failed to capitalized and punted, only to have Clavin score a 92-yard punt return with 6:28 left in the first quarter.
It didn’t take too long for St. Francis to get on the board as quarterback Miles Bryant connected with receiver Daniel Scott for a 61-yard reception before Harrick ran it in for a 4-yard TD to tie it up with 4:24 left in the quarter.
The scoring barrage in the first quarter didn’t end there. The Phantoms converted third-and-long with a 31-yard completion before Tovar ran 28 yards to score and take a 14-6 lead with 25.7 seconds left.
After keeping possession for more than five minutes, the Golden Knights drove all the way to the end zone, with Harrick scoring his second touchdown of the night with 4:49 left in the half.
The Phantoms were stumped going into halftime.
Foster answered Clavin’s punt return midway into the third quarter, scoring his very own 91-yard punt return to give the Golden Knights their first lead of the game with 5:40 left in the third.
Advertisement
St. Francis kicker Dulles Hanula made a 33-yard field goal to give the Golden Knights a 24-14 lead with 8:43 to go in the fourth. Foster sealed the deal when he ran it home from 18 yards for his second touchdown of the night.
“We’re going to let this one sink in for a little bit,” said Foster.
